description.plain:
Lord Huron is an American indie folk band based in Los Angeles that consists of Ben Schneider, Mark Barry, Miguel Briseño, and Tom Renaud. The group’s debut album, Lonesome Dreams, was released in 2012 on Iamsound in the U.S. and Play It Again Sam in UK & Ireland in January 2013.

The band’s name was inspired by Lake Huron, a lake which frontman, Ben Schneider, grew up visiting.

description.plain:
The final track on Strange Trails brings the listener down from the victory found in the previous track “Louisa.” It would be passable to end the album with the newfound love and resurrection in “Louisa,” but in keeping with the darker, desperate nature of the album, “The Night We Met” serves as more of a question mark rather than an exclamation point.

The song gained popularity after it appeared in the first season of the Netflix original show 13 Reasons Why.  When season two was released on May 18th, 2018, a remix of “The Night We Met” was included in the soundtrack with guest vocals from Phoebe Bridgers.

“The Night We Met” was also used in S1E18 of CW’s The Flash, more specifically when Barry and Felicity are sitting on the chairs in Jitters.  The song is played in the background, however, most fans of the show didn’t catch it until after 13 Reasons Why was released.

description.plain:
“Ends of the Earth”, the opening track of the album, is actually the fourth installment of the Lonesome Dreams series by GRJ. Lord Huron (our main character) has an adventurous spirit while deeply in love with this girl named Helen. He’s ready to see the world and won’t even stop at their love, but implores Helen to come with him. The song ends with his realization that he’s headed off on his own, ready to face the risks that come with a journey of this magnitude.

The setting of this dialogue should be thought of in the nighttime. While Time to Run had an upbeat, racy sound, the calming instrumentals in “Ends of the Earth” sound aid this image of Huron making a last plea to Helen to come with him right before he escapes into the darkness. He is asking her to follow him into the great unknown. An ultimate adventure.

description.plain:
In “Fool for Love” our main character is putting his money where his mouth is and will try to wrestle Lily away from “Big Jim”.

The names in this song mirror that of the Bob Dylan ballad “Lily, Rosemary, and the Jack of Hearts”. This ballad, in my opinion, not only paves the way for this song (which is most likely a prelude to Dylan’s) but for all of LH’s discography.

description.plain:
This could be the foreshadowing for the rest of the story, as the main character will soon have first hand experience with death.

Another possibility, perhaps the more controversial one, is that this song is playing off of the last song on their Lonesome Dreams album. In “In the Wind”, our female lead is left to believe that “death is a wall but it can’t be the end”. Their love has transcended the “end” and they are now loving as ghosts.

description.plain:
“Wait by the River” is about waiting for a second chance at love that will not come.

Ben in an interview with NPR a day before Vide Noir’s release:

I conceived it as sort of a nocturnal journey through the city where you encounter these different stories along the way. And part of the way I thought about it was you wander into these different clubs that have different styles of music or different types of people inhabiting them. So there’s sort of a through line in terms of the story. I think the way it begins and ends are the two ends of that person’s journey, but along the way, we kind of take all these twists and turns and wander through portals to other places.'

description.plain:
“Ancient Names, Pt. I” was released alongside “Ancient Names, Pt. II” on January 26, 2018; which was also the day which the band announced Vide Noir and its release date.

The lyrics throughout the song seem to be related to that of the occult, as well as superstition. These dark themes carry through with the album’s stylistically dark subject matter.

Frontman Ben Schneider in an interview with Stereogum when asked about the lyrics:

I think it’s just an interesting way to think about the future or your fate or whatever’s coming your way — to consider if there was some way to foresee that at all. And a big thing I was thinking about with this record: I’m all for science and I believe in it and I’m happy to see a lot of the destructive superstitions and strange beliefs we’ve developed over the years being destroyed with our scientific discoveries.

description.plain: The main character has been abandoned by his lover in this opening track to Lord Huron’s Vide Noir. This leaves this man not only confused and isolated, but haunted. He drowns his sorrows in “cocktail bars” and spends days searching for his lovers long-lost face. He feels aimless and left adrift in this black void. Hoping that if he crys out the name of his loved one enough, she’ll return…

He drowns his sorrows in “cocktail bars” and spends days searching for his lovers long-lost face. He feels aimless and left adrift in this black void. Hoping that if he crys out the name of his loved one enough, she’ll return…

songs.lyrics:
Lost in time and space
Aimless drifting into a far off place
Hurtling through the vast unknown
Staring straight into the pure, black void
Drowning in the sea of stars
Lost in a galaxy of cocktail bars
Blinded by the neon lights
I lie awake and say your name into the night

I guess she’s gone for good
She don’t call me like I thought she would
She went west to chase her dreams
She took my money, but she didn’t take me
Why go wander unknown worlds?
Stay right here and let the cosmos twirl
Blind without her source of light
I light a flame and say her name into the night

I don’t know who I am, I don’t know where I am

Lost in time and space
Aimless searching for a long, lost face
Haven’t got a thing to lose
If I don’t find her, gonna tie that noose
I quit my job and packed my car
Left in a hurry, and I've sure come far
Driving fast with no headlights
I’m wide awake, I say her name into the night
Oh, I'll find a way, I say your name into the night

I don’t know who I am, I don’t know where I am
I don’t know who I am, I don’t know where I am
I don’t know who I am, I don’t know where I am
I don’t know who I am, I don’t know where I am

description.plain:
“The World Ender” is a song about the gang created by Cobb Avery in his journey to avenge his family. In the comic book Lord Huron created to accompany the album, Cobb Avery built a house on land purchased from Andrew Winthop, who sold it to him knowing a sinkhole was underneath. The sinkhole consumed Cobb’s house and killed his family, causing him to go on a journey of revenge and assemble a group of the “scariest sons of bitches” that would be called The World Enders.

In an interview with NPR, lead singer Ben Schnieder described the song this way:

So it’s kind of just the tale of this working-class guy whose life kind of gets pulled out from under him, but he comes back to seek revenge this greaser gang called The World Enders. And they’re just kind of your traditional leather-jacket-wearing, slicked-back-hair, punk kids who kind of run around in these desert towns and cause trouble. And the idea behind this song was to kind of tell the origins of that gang. And I was kind of reading a lot of weird fiction and comic books at the time, and I wanted this to feel sort of like, you know, an origin story from a comic book.

description.plain:
“Vide Noir” is about the effects the drug Vide Noir has on the narrator. This song may have the same narrator as the man looking for his lost love, such as “Lost in Time and Space” and “Moonbeam.”

Frontman Ben In an NPR interview published a day before Vide Noir’s release:

[It’s] how I imagine the city sometimes. It’s this thing you can get sucked into it, sort of forever lost. But maybe there’s something kind of beautiful about it, too, and kind of giving yourself over to the to the void. A lot of the record deals with just kind of facing the realities of the universe and I think that’s staring into the void.

description.plain: “Emerald Star”, as the final track of the album, marks the main character’s realization that the girl – his long-lost love that he wants to save from the mysterious drug Vide Noir – does not need his help, and would rather stay intoxicated than reciprocate his love.

description.plain:
Track 3 begins with a hopeful, familiar air about it but soon diffuses towards the end of the song. Track 4, Ghost on the Shore, picks up on this sullen vibe immediately.

I take this song as Lord Huron’s acknowledgment of what he has left. The romanticism laced around the thought of adventure is dangerous, especially when you leave the love of your life (and break the law) to go on it.

One could even draw a parallel to Gatsby in F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic novel. Gatsby stands on the shore watching the green light across the sound. Lord Huron could be doing much of the same. Pining for the life he has left from a distant shore.

Lord Huron says he’s going away for a long time. Away from the shore, and away from Helen, his love.

description.plain: While this is the third track on the album, it is actually the 1st novel by the fictitious author, George Ranger Johnson. This changes the interpretation of the song from being Lord Huron’s arrival on this island to GRJ’s (George Ranger Johnson) setting of the scenes for the rest of the novels. This “lonesome dream” sets up the landscape for the rest of the story line.

description.plain: “Secret of Life” picks up the tempo after the crooning fifth track, “Wait by the River.” This song involves a character trapped by a curse by another character (presumably a woman). The woman showed the main character a type of magic she used so she would never die, but released something into the world in the process. The main character is trapped by a curse. Resigned to his fate, all he wants is to get high off some Vide Noir.

description.plain:
Frontman Ben Schneider has stated that “The Balancer’s Eye” is a track which the band created themselves, while making up their own myths as they went along.

Ben in an interview with Stereogum:

“Balancer’s Eye” is one we created ourselves, making up our own myths as we go. We’re trying to keep it so all that stuff is still around in this world too. You’ll see things that appeared on other records, ideas or names cross over to [Vide Noir]. In movies and literature and comic books, I’ve always liked where there’s connectedness or crossover. We need someone to control the lore and keep tabs on it [laughs].

body.plain:
Frontman Ben Schneider has stated that “The Balancer’s Eye” is a track which the band created themselves, while making up their own myths as they went along.

Ben in an interview with Stereogum:

“Balancer’s Eye” is one we created ourselves, making up our own myths as we go. We’re trying to keep it so all that stuff is still around in this world too. You’ll see things that appeared on other records, ideas or names cross over to [Vide Noir]. In movies and literature and comic books, I’ve always liked where there’s connectedness or crossover. We need someone to control the lore and keep tabs on it [laughs].

description.plain:
The third installment of GRJ’s novels (and track two on the album) finds our main character Lord Huron on the run. Time to Run, of the Lonesome Dreams series starts off with a bang (literally, in the music video). The scene should be thought of in the same vein as Ends of the Earth, as it’s Lord Huron pleading his case to Helen. This time, though, the tone is rushed and it’s made clear in the first line alone that LH has done something illegal (or against the wishes of those in town).

A chase scene can be pictured here, as Lord Huron runs away from the law and makes a last ditch effort to get Helen to come with him.

description.plain:
This song is an interesting one narrative wise, in that the character, H.W. Justine, is only mentioned here. Although, it’s possible there’s a connection between this and one of the two “Traditional” songs on the album.

The song is about isolation, and being stuck in time.

songs.lyrics:
Yellow lines in the dead of the night
Oh, I was heading back out west
Trying to keep my eyes open wide
I'd gone days without any rest
Saw him lying in the road looking bad
About 20 yards ahead
You come back from a trip to the East
But you don't come back from the dead

Sure as hell, he was dead as they come
And he was already starting to smell
Just a kid with his hair slicked back
And a knife tucked into his belt
Was he unforgiven or just tired of living a life
That never felt like his?
Though I was was worn and weary, I thought I'd bury him
And lay his soul to rest out in the desert night

I laid him down in a grave in the sand
And he grabbed my arm with his dead man's hand
He said: "I know I'm dead, but I don't wanna lie
In a grave out here where the coyotes cry
I stared right into the endless void
And I ain't going back if I got any choice
I know how to live, I don't know how to die
And there ain't no thrills in the afterlife

So lift me up out of here, my friend
And I'll wander the night till the ages end"
Lit by the moon, he walked through the sand
And he waved goodbye with his dead man's hand


And he will roam forever, haunting the desert
And he will roam forever, haunting the desert

description.plain:
Buck Vernon finds himself completely at the whim of another woman – who this woman is, is hard to say. Buck Vernon seems to have a history as a hopeless romantic, chasing people he shouldn’t chase.

This could still be Lily, or Louisa, or someone else.

description.plain: “Back From the Edge” is about someone who survived being blackbrained, or an overdose of Vide Noir. As depicted in “Products of the Universe with Marsha Tanley,” blackbraining someone is the preferred method for the gang to kill their victims. The narrator of this song may have survived an attempt on their life, or overdosed by their own actions.

description.plain:
This is the 5th GRJ installment in the series.

Easily the most romantic song of the entire series. Once again, Huron continues his fascination with death. He admits once again that we’re all going to die

Huron understands that he will die, but his love for Helen never will. He wants to live forever because he loves this life (and Helen) so much.

description.plain:
This is the second time in the story Helen is introduced as a narrator. She is describing Huron’s return to her after the encounter he had with his “Brother” Admiral Blaquefut against those who wanted to hang him.

He returns to Helen bloodied but still alive and with the seemingly chase about to resume again, Helen stops him and tells him to sleep.

description.plain: Presumably a song revolving around Huron and Blaquefut’s relationship. Narrated by Huron, he calls to Blaquefut, asking him to end this fight and restore their relationship to what it once was- brotherhood. Huron acknowledges the fight and chaos to come, but pleads to Blaquefut to end it all and join forces to stop it instead of pitting against each other. Even though Blaquefut denies their relationship and connection, Huron suggests they come together to defeat “the fire” as one. It is unknown as to whether this plea for peace is successful.

description.plain: Huron is angry with presumably Helen, for loving another man after he had left. After making it clear that he would wait for her forever, her feelings did not reciprocate. He compares himself to her new beau, and questioning her decision. Huron proposes that Helen’s new love is not as committed as he is, and is not willing to give everything for her. Huron is “willing to die” for Helen; telling her that he still loves and cares for her. He insists that he has changed and is ready for her return to him, even though he thinks she is gone for good.

You've been running 'round again

Now that the deed is done
I'm just waiting for night
And the fading light of the setting sun
Tell me when did I lose your love?
Was it him you were thinking of
All those nights when you made me swoon
Making love beneath the moon?
Were you dreaming of his touch?
When you couldn't get enough
Was there truth in the songs you sung?
Little girl, you're not so young
Well, I could never betray your love
You had me, heart and soul
You might never have known it, girl
But I was all yours
I know I'll never reclaim your love
But that's just how it goes
I ain't the person I was this morning when the sun rose
Well, I could never betray your love
You had me, heart and soul
You might never have known it, girl
But I was all yours
I know I'll never reclaim your love
But that's just how it goes
I ain't the person I was this morning when the sun rose
I know I'll never replace your love and that's as hard as it gets
So I'll be taking a life this evening when the sun sets

description.plain: In Lord Huron’s second solo project and EP, Mighty, created, recorded and sung by Ben Schneider only, When Will I See You Again is the last track. It’s a story, I believe, about scorned love. How a woman or man could’ve cheated on their spouse and they’re leaving and the significant other seems okay with it, but still wants to see them again, but at the same time, angry.

It’s a story, I believe, about scorned love. How a woman or man could’ve cheated on their spouse and they’re leaving and the significant other seems okay with it, but still wants to see them again, but at the same time, angry.

songs.lyrics:
If you got what you came for, why should you stay?
If you know where you're going, why delay?
If you won't be returning, don't say goodbye.
Turn your back on the ocean, follow the sun through the sky.
When will I see you again?
When will I see you again?
When will I see you again?
When will I see you again?
I've already forgotten all of your names.
And I cannot remember when you came.
Grab your things and get going, don't say goodbye.
Turn your back on the ocean, go see what's out there to find.
It's time to let go,
Goodbye and so long.
All the best along the way,
Couldn't I keep you another day?(x2)
When will I see you again?
When?
When Will I see you again?
When?
When will I see you again.
When?
When will I see you again?
When?
When will I see you again?(x2)

description.plain:
In “Into the Sun,” the protagonist fantasizes about escaping on a boat rather than continuing to put up with the monotony of daily life. If he were to die in the process of getting away, he feels that it would still be worth the risk.
